channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Ukraine’s president warned of a “new stage of terror” by Russian forces, after what he said was the kidnapping of a mayor in the south of the country as well as a fresh round of airstrikes on the outskirts of the capital https://t.co/qBoGQESQMz

From @WSJopinion: If Olaf Scholz succeeds, Germany will achieve the kind of European and global leadership Angela Merkel could only pretend at, writes @josephsternberg. This will transform Europe. And what a prize if it works. https://t.co/WtS6EQlYVb
From the Russian Revolution to Vietnam, war has been a reliable precursor to inflation, and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine appears to be no different, writes @greg_ip https://t.co/eAueOIPgpk
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/3ylLBdd6Lz https://t.co/Z3lcH0aeCU

The U.S. moved to sever normal trade ties with Russia—and ban imports of its seafood, vodka and diamonds—as it joined other countries in ratcheting up economic pressure on Moscow for its invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/sCVnUwot7D
"He probably knows his mama is dead." A Ukrainian father waits outside his 7-year-old boy's hospital room in Kharkiv, a city left in rubble by Russian missiles. https://t.co/EOqETxdYe2
Here is an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal's weekend edition https://t.co/Y5HsuZeQvf https://t.co/CSQdbtmvT2
Russian forces fired cluster weapons on multiple occasions in Ukraine, watchdog groups said. Moscow denied the allegations. Here’s how they work. https://t.co/pxIhK35BQE

President Biden said Russia would pay a “severe price” if it used chemical weapons as Western officials grow increasingly worried that Moscow will resort to deploying chemical, biological or nuclear weapons after struggling to make headway in Ukraine https://t.co/NLplNXNCdq

India said that it accidentally fired a missile into Pakistan this week, blaming a “technical malfunction” for a mishap that could fire up tensions between the nuclear-armed neighbors https://t.co/7LhP6Vylr5
Stolichnaya vodka’s hard-to-shake Soviet-era hangover: Many drinkers and bartenders think it’s Russian. So the Latvia-bottled spirit is rebranding. https://t.co/soDDgyKFvR
From @WSJopinion: By seizing the nuclear plants, Russia is able to retake the market for Ukrainian nuclear fuel, writes @jeffsmerrifield https://t.co/UOtMg4U5Zd

An unusual and mostly forgotten pledge Chinese President Xi Jinping signed in 2013 that China would protect Ukraine in the event of a nuclear attack is getting fresh attention following Russia’s invasion of its neighbor https://t.co/UrG4376T4P

Escalating conflict between Russia and Ukraine has sent investors to safer assets, propelling the dollar to its highest level since pandemic-induced volatility in 2020 #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/w6uWRcBPVL https://t.co/gE5w4KcIYZ
A number of U.S. hedge-fund firms that have investments from Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich have been told to freeze his assets https://t.co/9H9x6XgoVF
"It's a war, and it's a dirty war." Residents of Ukraine's second-largest city aid the wounded and clear rubble from Russian missile attacks. https://t.co/OlXz8J6Bht

The U.S. moved to sever normal trade ties with Russia—and ban imports of its seafood, vodka and diamonds—as it joined other countries in ratcheting up economic pressure on Moscow for its invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/zEIOytaHUB
From @WSJopinion: Biden can talk all he wants about his plans to cripple Putin’s economy. He has yet to take the steps that might actually do it, writes @KimStrassel. https://t.co/0YVUrH5Q36

An unusual and mostly forgotten pledge Chinese President Xi Jinping signed in 2013 that China would protect Ukraine in the event of a nuclear attack is getting fresh attention following Russia’s invasion of its neighbor https://t.co/qbd2pu9INO

India said that it accidentally fired a missile into Pakistan this week, blaming a “technical malfunction” for a mishap that could fire up tensions between the nuclear-armed neighbors https://t.co/FVkjZ5FUrm
Stolichnaya vodka’s hard-to-shake Soviet-era hangover: Many drinkers and bartenders think it’s Russian. So the Latvia-bottled spirit is rebranding. https://t.co/odQMzujdMy

From an emergency operations center in Sacramento, California National Guard members are helping members of the Ukrainian military whom they have trained in a close partnership over many years https://t.co/momG790cfQ
The U.S. is extending its mask mandate for travelers on airplanes and other forms of transit through April 18, the CDC said https://t.co/rGy26e0CCN
Vice President Kamala Harris said during a news conference Friday that intentional attacks on civilians are war crimes https://t.co/y42CDhNqt9
President Biden received favorable marks for his handling of the Ukraine crisis, a new WSJ poll found, but 57% of voters remain unhappy with his job performance https://t.co/5EIDnMKWA6

President Biden said Russia would pay a “severe price” if it used chemical weapons as Western officials grow increasingly worried that Moscow will resort to deploying chemical, biological or nuclear weapons after struggling to make headway in Ukraine https://t.co/aWPnUc7Xq7
A video depicting Russian cosmonauts abandoning a U.S. astronaut at the International Space Station prompted former NASA astronaut Scott Kelly to call out Russia's space chief https://t.co/U2Uc6rZSmE
Emilio Delgado, who played the Fix-It Shop owner Luis on “Sesame Street” for more than 40 years, died Thursday after a longtime illness. He was 81. https://t.co/wKwA5mxV8C
From @WSJopinion: We admire Volodymyr Zelensky and want to help Ukraine, writes @Peggynoonannyc. But escalation poses threats far beyond its borders. https://t.co/VvE0XtxB0u
"He probably knows his mama is dead." A Ukrainian father waits outside his 7-year-old boy's hospital room in Kharkiv, a city left in rubble by Russian missiles. https://t.co/Sw1MApGtHZ
The Ukraine war has added urgency to the Biden administration’s monthslong search for new oil supplies, as it seeks to contain surging energy prices https://t.co/CdDgApyhkv

President Biden said the U.S. will move to revoke normal trade relations with Russia, joining Western allies in a coordinated action to further punish Moscow for the war in Ukraine https://t.co/qQke3w798U
From @WSJopinion: We already knew that Putin was angry, arrogant and autocratic. We have learned that he is also more reckless than we had appreciated, writes @MichaelEOHanlon https://t.co/35gmAwOFEB

The U.S. is planning to ban imports of Russian alcohol and seafood, according to people familiar with the matter, in the latest effort to punish Moscow for the country’s invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/ejIVI53Fgf

An unusual and mostly forgotten pledge Chinese President Xi Jinping signed in 2013 that China would protect Ukraine in the event of a nuclear attack is getting fresh attention following Russia’s invasion of its neighbor https://t.co/PPkVyMJb8y
Russian forces fired cluster weapons on multiple occasions in Ukraine, watchdog groups said. Moscow denied the allegations. Here’s how they work. https://t.co/h3jCOIJqKe
The EU and the U.K. are investigating possible price fixing by Google and Meta, a rare probe into whether two tech giants acted together to thwart competitors https://t.co/2oNea2CqEH
In Ukraine, a ballet dancer, a rock singer, a playwright all take up arms with tens of thousands of Ukrainian civilians to fight Russia’s invasion https://t.co/xgs5YbZkC2

Russian officials accused the U.S. of funding biowarfare efforts in Ukraine, stirring fears that the claims could be a pretext for Moscow to unleash chemical or biological weapons https://t.co/e0fUaPXOLh
Russian forces launched a fresh assault on the besieged city of Mariupol, a day after one of its planes bombed a maternity hospital https://t.co/KrYNqMrUDf
Actor Jussie Smollett has been sentenced to 150 days in jail for reporting a false hate crime to Chicago police in January 2019 https://t.co/Y5Gnzg4t68
Senate Democrats and Republicans reached an agreement to vote on a $1.5 trillion measure that funds the government and provides aid for Ukraine https://t.co/1EIdDm2NMm

Essay: To show solidarity with Ukraine, many cultural organizations have cut ties with Russia. But ascribing Putin’s brutality to every Russian writer and artist denies the essence of art, writes Suzanne Nossel. https://t.co/P1Oxg3V0Nq
President Biden is expected to announce Friday that the U.S. will join major allies and the EU in calling to revoke normal trade relations with Russia https://t.co/opPfA0h6DH

Ukrainian authorities raised the casualty count of Wednesday’s hospital bombing in Mariupol to three dead and 17 wounded. Vice President Kamala Harris called for a war crimes investigation Thursday, adding that Russia was committing atrocities in Ukraine. https://t.co/VUDpoALnyP

Facebook's parent company has temporarily altered its political expression policy to allow for some use of violent speech, saying exceptions were put in place because of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and allow for speech like “death to the Russian invaders" https://t.co/0zwPXtHmuU

On Thursday 42 Republican senators, led by Sens. Joni Ernst and Mitt Romney, wrote to President Biden that they "strongly disagree with the Defense Department's decision to delay and deny Poland the option to transfer fighter jets to Ukraine." https://t.co/F2lVbf0Tmo

Speaking at the Democratic National Committee meeting, President Biden said the U.S. is “increasing oil production” and said to oil companies: “A time of war is not a time for profit.” https://t.co/sutvMDCJZf
The Pentagon is exploring ways to shore up Ukraine’s air defenses by facilitating the transfer of Soviet-designed antiaircraft systems like the S-300 https://t.co/OnXvE35NtW
Disney said Thursday it is taking steps to pause all other businesses in Russia, a move that comes after it paused the release of films in Russia https://t.co/zyJEKDL25p
